title: Kalevi Aho
text:
Kalevi Ensio Aho (born 9 March 1949) is a <a href="Finnish%20people">Finnish</a> composer.
Early years.
Aho began his interest in music at the age of ten, when he discovered a <a href="mandolin">mandolin</a> in his home and began to teach himself how to play it. He soon was taken under the tutelage of Martti Loikkanen, the boy's 4th grade teacher and founder of a local youth mandolin ensemble in <a href="Forssa">Forssa</a>. After learning how to read sheet music, Aho immediately started composing. Aho progressed so fast on the instrument that Loikkanen suggested he study the <a href="violin">violin</a> as well, with Loikkanen giving him private lessons. Aho also began to learn violin at an incredible speed, with him later recalling, "Martti taught me at home for free until I started skipping him out of my playing skills and he suggested changing teachers." Aho's parents were quite supportive of his musical hobby, encouraging him to compose and giving him a piano at the age of 15.
Career.
He moved from the city of Forssa to <a href="Helsinki">Helsinki</a> in September 1968 to study at the <a href="Sibelius%20Academy">Sibelius Academy</a>. He studied composition at the <a href="Sibelius%20Academy">Sibelius Academy</a> under <a href="Einojuhani%20Rautavaara">Einojuhani Rautavaara</a>, beginning that year and receiving a diploma in 1971. He continued his studies for a year in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> with <a href="Boris%20Blacher">Boris Blacher</a>. His teaching positions include music theory at the <a href="University%20of%20Helsinki">University of Helsinki</a> from 1974–88, and a professorship at the Sibelius Academy from 1988–93. He was named composer-in-residence for the <a href="Lahti%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Lahti Symphony Orchestra</a> in 1992, and conductor <a href="Osmo%20V%C3%A4nsk%C3%A4">Osmo Vänskä</a> has recorded many of his recent large-scale works with the orchestra. Aho has worked as a freelance composer, with a state scholarship, since 1993. He lives in <a href="Helsinki">Helsinki</a>.
Music.
Known principally as a composer of large-scale works, Aho has composed seventeen <a href="symphony">symphonies</a>, thirty-six <a href="concertos">concertos</a>, five <a href="opera">opera</a>s and several vocal works. His chamber music includes several <a href="quintet">quintet</a>s, <a href="quartet">quartet</a>s, <a href="sonata">sonata</a>s and solo works. He first came to fame with his first symphony (1969) and second string quartet (1970).
His works of this time showed such <a href="Neoclassicism%20%28music%29">neo-classical</a> traits as a preoccupation with <a href="counterpoint">counterpoint</a> (particularly <a href="fugue">fugue</a>s), and stylized renderings of older forms, such as the <a href="waltz">waltz</a>. In the following decade he wrote in <a href="modernist">modernist</a> and <a href="post-modernist">post-modernist</a> styles. His use of irony and juxtaposition of contrasting moods and musical styles and genres has been compared to <a href="Gustav%20Mahler">Gustav Mahler</a> and <a href="Alfred%20Schnittke">Alfred Schnittke</a>.
